div.l: And when that dronken was halfden þe rowt
To bedd went the douȝtir riȝte a noon
To bedd went Aleyn and also Iohn
There was no more ther͗e nedith hem no dwale
The Miller hath so wisly bibbit ale
That as an hors he rowtith in his sclepe
Ne of his tayll be hynde he toke no kepe
His wyff bare hym a burdon ful strong
Men myȝte here hem rowting a furlong
The wench rowtid eke per company
Aleyn the Clerk that herd this melody
He plukkid Iohn and seyd sclepist thow
Herist þow what such a song is now
Lo wich a company is a mong hem all
A wild feir on hir body fall
Who herd evir such a ferly thing
They shall have the floure of evill ending
Al this long nyȝt ther͗e tidith me no rest
But ȝit no force al shal be for the best
For Iohn seyd as evir mut I thryve
If that I may the maide well I swyve
Som esement hath law shapyn vs
For Iohn ther͗e is a law þat seith thus
That yff a man in o poynt be grevid
That in a nothir he may be relevid
Our corn is stole sothly it is no nay
And wee have had an evil fit to day
And sith I shall have noon Amendement
Ageyn myne los I woll have some esement
By Goddis saouwle sawle saouwle it shall be noon othir
Iohn seyd to Aleyn Avise the leve brothir
The Millere is a ꝑperlouse man he seyde
And yf he oute of his sclepe a breyd
He myȝt do vs both vylany
Aleyn Answerd I count hym nat a fly
And he vp risith and to the wench he crepe
